<a id="float"></a>

# float

A built-in type for floating-point numbers.

<!-- classref-introduction-group -->

## Description

The **float** built-in type is a 64-bit double-precision floating-point number, equivalent to ``double`` in C++. This type has 14 reliable decimal digits of precision. The maximum value of **float** is approximately ``1.79769e308``, and the minimum is approximately ``-1.79769e308``.

Many methods and properties in the engine use 32-bit single-precision floating-point numbers instead, equivalent to ``float`` in C++, which have 6 reliable decimal digits of precision. For data structures such as [Vector2](Vector2.md) and [Vector3](Vector3.md), Redot uses 32-bit floating-point numbers by default, but it can be changed to use 64-bit doubles if Redot is compiled with the ``precision=double`` option.

Math done using the **float** type is not guaranteed to be exact and will often result in small errors. You should usually use the [@GlobalScope.is_equal_approx()](@GlobalScope.md#@GlobalScope_method_is_equal_approx) and [@GlobalScope.is_zero_approx()](@GlobalScope.md#@GlobalScope_method_is_zero_approx) methods instead of ``==`` to compare **float** values for equality.

<!-- classref-introduction-group -->

## Tutorials

- [Wikipedia: Double-precision floating-point format](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double-precision_floating-point_format)

- [Wikipedia: Single-precision floating-point format](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Single-precision_floating-point_format)

## Constructor Descriptions

<a id="float_constructor_float"></a>

<!-- classref-constructor -->

[float](float.md) **float**\ (\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_constructor_float)

Constructs a default-initialized **float** set to ``0.0``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<!-- classref-constructor -->

[float](float.md) **float**\ (\ from\: [float](float.md)\ )

Constructs a **float** as a copy of the given **float**.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<!-- classref-constructor -->

[float](float.md) **float**\ (\ from\: [String](String.md)\ )

Converts a [String](String.md) to a **float**, following the same rules as [String.to_float()](String.md#String_method_to_float).

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<!-- classref-constructor -->

[float](float.md) **float**\ (\ from\: [bool](bool.md)\ )

Cast a [bool](bool.md) value to a floating-point value, ``float(true)`` will be equal to 1.0 and ``float(false)`` will be equal to 0.0.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<!-- classref-constructor -->

[float](float.md) **float**\ (\ from\: [int](int.md)\ )

Cast an [int](int.md) value to a floating-point value, ``float(1)`` will be equal to ``1.0``.

<hr class="classref-section-separator"/>

<!-- classref-descriptions-group -->

## Operator Descriptions

<a id="float_operator_neq_float"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](bool.md) **operator !=**\ (\ right\: [float](float.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_neq_float)

Returns ``true`` if two floats are different from each other.

\ **Note:** [@GDScript.NAN](@GDScript.md#@GDScript_constant_NAN) doesn't behave the same as other numbers. Therefore, the results from this operator may not be accurate if NaNs are included.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_neq_int"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](bool.md) **operator !=**\ (\ right\: [int](int.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_neq_int)

Returns ``true`` if the integer has different value than the float.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_mul_Color"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Color](Color.md) **operator ***\ (\ right\: [Color](Color.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_mul_Color)

Multiplies each component of the [Color](Color.md), including the alpha, by the given **float**.

```
    print(1.5 * Color(0.5, 0.5, 0.5)) # Prints (0.75, 0.75, 0.75, 1.5)
```


<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_mul_Quaternion"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Quaternion](Quaternion.md) **operator ***\ (\ right\: [Quaternion](Quaternion.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_mul_Quaternion)

Multiplies each component of the [Quaternion](Quaternion.md) by the given **float**. This operation is not meaningful on its own, but it can be used as a part of a larger expression.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_mul_Vector2"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector2](Vector2.md) **operator ***\ (\ right\: [Vector2](Vector2.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_mul_Vector2)

Multiplies each component of the [Vector2](Vector2.md) by the given **float**.

```
    print(2.5 * Vector2(1, 3)) # Prints (2.5, 7.5)
```


<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_mul_Vector2i"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector2](Vector2.md) **operator ***\ (\ right\: [Vector2i](Vector2i.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_mul_Vector2i)

Multiplies each component of the [Vector2i](Vector2i.md) by the given **float**. Returns a [Vector2](Vector2.md).

```
    print(0.9 * Vector2i(10, 15)) # Prints (9.0, 13.5)
```


<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_mul_Vector3"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector3](Vector3.md) **operator ***\ (\ right\: [Vector3](Vector3.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_mul_Vector3)

Multiplies each component of the [Vector3](Vector3.md) by the given **float**.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_mul_Vector3i"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector3](Vector3.md) **operator ***\ (\ right\: [Vector3i](Vector3i.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_mul_Vector3i)

Multiplies each component of the [Vector3i](Vector3i.md) by the given **float**. Returns a [Vector3](Vector3.md).

```
    print(0.9 * Vector3i(10, 15, 20)) # Prints (9.0, 13.5, 18.0)
```


<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_mul_Vector4"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4](Vector4.md) **operator ***\ (\ right\: [Vector4](Vector4.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_mul_Vector4)

Multiplies each component of the [Vector4](Vector4.md) by the given **float**.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_mul_Vector4i"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4](Vector4.md) **operator ***\ (\ right\: [Vector4i](Vector4i.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_mul_Vector4i)

Multiplies each component of the [Vector4i](Vector4i.md) by the given **float**. Returns a [Vector4](Vector4.md).

```
    print(0.9 * Vector4i(10, 15, 20, -10)) # Prints (9.0, 13.5, 18.0, -9.0)
```


<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_mul_float"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[float](float.md) **operator ***\ (\ right\: [float](float.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_mul_float)

Multiplies two **float**\\ s.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_mul_int"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[float](float.md) **operator ***\ (\ right\: [int](int.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_mul_int)

Multiplies a **float** and an [int](int.md). The result is a **float**.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_pow_float"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[float](float.md) **operator ****\ (\ right\: [float](float.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_pow_float)

Raises a **float** to a power of a **float**.

```
    print(39.0625**0.25) # 2.5
```


<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_pow_int"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[float](float.md) **operator ****\ (\ right\: [int](int.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_pow_int)

Raises a **float** to a power of an [int](int.md). The result is a **float**.

```
    print(0.9**3) # 0.729
```


<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_sum_float"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[float](float.md) **operator +**\ (\ right\: [float](float.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_sum_float)

Adds two floats.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_sum_int"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[float](float.md) **operator +**\ (\ right\: [int](int.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_sum_int)

Adds a **float** and an [int](int.md). The result is a **float**.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_dif_float"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[float](float.md) **operator -**\ (\ right\: [float](float.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_dif_float)

Subtracts a float from a float.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_dif_int"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[float](float.md) **operator -**\ (\ right\: [int](int.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_dif_int)

Subtracts an [int](int.md) from a **float**. The result is a **float**.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_div_float"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[float](float.md) **operator /**\ (\ right\: [float](float.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_div_float)

Divides two floats.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_div_int"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[float](float.md) **operator /**\ (\ right\: [int](int.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_div_int)

Divides a **float** by an [int](int.md). The result is a **float**.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_lt_float"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](bool.md) **operator &lt;**\ (\ right\: [float](float.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_lt_float)

Returns ``true`` if the left float is less than the right one.

\ **Note:** [@GDScript.NAN](@GDScript.md#@GDScript_constant_NAN) doesn't behave the same as other numbers. Therefore, the results from this operator may not be accurate if NaNs are included.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_lt_int"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](bool.md) **operator &lt;**\ (\ right\: [int](int.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_lt_int)

Returns ``true`` if this **float** is less than the given [int](int.md).

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_lte_float"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](bool.md) **operator &lt;=**\ (\ right\: [float](float.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_lte_float)

Returns ``true`` if the left float is less than or equal to the right one.

\ **Note:** [@GDScript.NAN](@GDScript.md#@GDScript_constant_NAN) doesn't behave the same as other numbers. Therefore, the results from this operator may not be accurate if NaNs are included.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_lte_int"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](bool.md) **operator &lt;=**\ (\ right\: [int](int.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_lte_int)

Returns ``true`` if this **float** is less than or equal to the given [int](int.md).

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_eq_float"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](bool.md) **operator ==**\ (\ right\: [float](float.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_eq_float)

Returns ``true`` if both floats are exactly equal.

\ **Note:** Due to floating-point precision errors, consider using [@GlobalScope.is_equal_approx()](@GlobalScope.md#@GlobalScope_method_is_equal_approx) or [@GlobalScope.is_zero_approx()](@GlobalScope.md#@GlobalScope_method_is_zero_approx) instead, which are more reliable.

\ **Note:** [@GDScript.NAN](@GDScript.md#@GDScript_constant_NAN) doesn't behave the same as other numbers. Therefore, the results from this operator may not be accurate if NaNs are included.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_eq_int"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](bool.md) **operator ==**\ (\ right\: [int](int.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_eq_int)

Returns ``true`` if the **float** and the given [int](int.md) are equal.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_gt_float"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](bool.md) **operator &gt;**\ (\ right\: [float](float.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_gt_float)

Returns ``true`` if the left float is greater than the right one.

\ **Note:** [@GDScript.NAN](@GDScript.md#@GDScript_constant_NAN) doesn't behave the same as other numbers. Therefore, the results from this operator may not be accurate if NaNs are included.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_gt_int"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](bool.md) **operator &gt;**\ (\ right\: [int](int.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_gt_int)

Returns ``true`` if this **float** is greater than the given [int](int.md).

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_gte_float"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](bool.md) **operator &gt;=**\ (\ right\: [float](float.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_gte_float)

Returns ``true`` if the left float is greater than or equal to the right one.

\ **Note:** [@GDScript.NAN](@GDScript.md#@GDScript_constant_NAN) doesn't behave the same as other numbers. Therefore, the results from this operator may not be accurate if NaNs are included.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_gte_int"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](bool.md) **operator &gt;=**\ (\ right\: [int](int.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_gte_int)

Returns ``true`` if this **float** is greater than or equal to the given [int](int.md).

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_unplus"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[float](float.md) **operator unary+**\ (\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_unplus)

Returns the same value as if the ``+`` was not there. Unary ``+`` does nothing, but sometimes it can make your code more readable.

<hr class="classref-item-separator"/>

<a id="float_operator_unminus"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[float](float.md) **operator unary-**\ (\ ) [ðŸ”—](#float_operator_unminus)

Returns the negative value of the **float**. If positive, turns the number negative. If negative, turns the number positive. With floats, the number zero can be either positive or negative.
